body:
Concept ACK!

This made me think that we should fail funding if some coin is already locked?

Added a release note.

> This made me think that we should fail funding if some coin is already locked?

Maybe in a separate PR. I also think it's safer for users to explicitly unlock coins before using them.

> I also think it's safer for users to explicitly unlock coins before using them.

The unspent locking was done to deal with concurrent clients and so a client shouldn't take the decision to unlock a coin so lightly - it might screw with a concurrent funding. This is a possible use case and for this reason the user should be able to lock all or nothing IMO.

> Maybe in a separate PR

~~Yes sure!~~ Well kind of, the lock-an-already-locked-coin-and-ignore behavior is added here :thinking:.

>  the lock-an-already-locked-coin-and-ignore behavior

Not sure what you mean. This PR can potentially lock a coin that's already locked, but why is that a problem? This PR does not ignore new things.
The problem is that you might screw with a concurrent funding. When you lock a coin you should expect that it won't be used by others.

If a concurrent wallet consumer uses manual coin selection, I don't think this PR makes their problem worse; we were already ignoring any lock they had. If it uses automatic automatic coin selection then this PR has no impact.
After [IRC discussion](http://www.erisian.com.au/bitcoin-core-dev/log-2020-03-06.html#l-288) I changed this PR to honour locks for manually selected coins.

<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

<!--174a7506f384e20aa4161008e828411d-->
### Conflicts
No conflicts as of last run.
concept ACK
Rebased
ACK 74992fd8cbe6f409bd1dad6c064deb5428509472
I'll await the above discussion. Will address nits if that leads to a change.

Based on the above discussion I changed this PR again, it now does the following:
1. lock all inputs for a transaction, rather than just the automatically selected ones
2. unchanged behaviour:  ignore lock on manually coins (with some tests)

I updated the description to clarify the discussion a bit.
Thanks @Sjors will review again.
Client-specific locks sounds fun, but not in this PR :-)

diff_hunk:
@@ -89,6 +89,15 @@ def run_test(self):
         final_tx = self.nodes[0].finalizepsbt(signed_tx)['hex']
         self.nodes[0].sendrawtransaction(final_tx)
 
+        # Manually selected inputs can be locked:
+        utxo1 = self.nodes[0].listunspent()[0]
+        psbtx1 = self.nodes[0].walletcreatefundedpsbt([{"txid": utxo1['txid'], "vout": utxo1['vout']}], {self.nodes[2].getnewaddress():1}, 0,{"lockUnspents": True})["psbt"]
+        assert_equal(len(self.nodes[0].listlockunspent()), 1)
body: `assert_equal(len(self.nodes[0].listlockunspent()), 0)` before `walletcreatefundedpsbt`?
space

diff_hunk:

                 "Temporarily lock (unlock=false) or unlock (unlock=true) specified transaction outputs.\n"
                 "If no transaction outputs are specified when unlocking then all current locked transaction outputs are unlocked.\n"
                 "A locked transaction output will not be chosen by automatic coin selection, when spending bitcoins.\n"
+                "With manual coin selection a locked transaction output must unlocked before use."
body: "... must be ..."

         self.nodes[1].lockunspent(False, [unspent_0])

body: Are you removing this case because it's used elsewhere?
The final frontier.

body: The original test was for auto-unlocking a coin, which now produces an error, so I check for that.

diff_hunk:
@@ -136,11 +136,20 @@ def run_test(self):
                                 self.nodes[2].lockunspent, False,
                                 [{"txid": unspent_0["txid"], "vout": 999}])
 
-        # An output should be unlocked when spent
+        # The lock on a manually selected output is honoured
         unspent_0 = self.nodes[1].listunspent()[0]
         self.nodes[1].lockunspent(False, [unspent_0])
         tx = self.nodes[1].createrawtransaction([unspent_0], { self.nodes[1].getnewaddress() : 1 })
-        tx = self.nodes[1].fundrawtransaction(tx)['hex']
+        assert_raises_rpc_error(-4, "Output " + unspent_0['txid'] + ":" + str(unspent_0['vout']) + " is locked",
+                                self.nodes[1].fundrawtransaction,tx,{"lockUnspents": True})
+
+        # fundrawtransaction can lock an input
+        self.nodes[1].lockunspent(True, [unspent_0])
+        assert_equal(len(self.nodes[1].listlockunspent()), 0)
+        tx = self.nodes[1].fundrawtransaction(tx,{"lockUnspents": True})['hex']
body: nit, add space if you happen to push again.

diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,8 @@
+Updated RPCs
+------------
+
+- `fundrawtransaction` and `walletcreatefundedpsbt` now abort if a manually selected
+  coin is locked. It must be manually unlocked with `lockunspent` before use.
body:
suggest stating `lockunspent` is an RPC, in contrast with the `lockUnspents` argument mentioned right after

```suggestion
  coin is locked; coins must be manually unlocked with RPC `lockunspent` before use.
```

diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,8 @@
+Updated RPCs
+------------
+
+- `fundrawtransaction` and `walletcreatefundedpsbt` now abort if a manually selected
+  coin is locked. It must be manually unlocked with `lockunspent` before use.
+  Previously they would merely avoid using locked coins in automatic
+  coin selection. When used with `lockUnspents`, these two RPC methods now lock manually
body:
suggest stating`lockUnspents` is an argument, in contrast to the `lockunspent` RPC mentioned right before

```suggestion
  coin selection. When used with the `lockUnspents` argument, these two RPCs now lock manually
```

diff_hunk:
@@ -2122,6 +2122,7 @@ static UniValue lockunspent(const JSONRPCRequest& request)
                 "Temporarily lock (unlock=false) or unlock (unlock=true) specified transaction outputs.\n"
                 "If no transaction outputs are specified when unlocking then all current locked transaction outputs are unlocked.\n"
                 "A locked transaction output will not be chosen by automatic coin selection, when spending bitcoins.\n"
+                "With manual coin selection a locked transaction output must be unlocked before use."
body:
missing newline at end of string here

current output is a too-long line and missing space between sentences: `before use.Locks are stored`:
```
With manual coin selection a locked transaction output must be unlocked before use.Locks are stored in memory only. Nodes start with zero locked outputs, and the locked output list
is always cleared (by virtue of process exit) when a node stops or fails.
```

diff_hunk:
@@ -2122,6 +2122,7 @@ static UniValue lockunspent(const JSONRPCRequest& request)
                 "Temporarily lock (unlock=false) or unlock (unlock=true) specified transaction outputs.\n"
                 "If no transaction outputs are specified when unlocking then all current locked transaction outputs are unlocked.\n"
                 "A locked transaction output will not be chosen by automatic coin selection, when spending bitcoins.\n"
+                "With manual coin selection a locked transaction output must be unlocked before use."
                 "Locks are stored in memory only. Nodes start with zero locked outputs, and the locked output list\n"
                 "is always cleared (by virtue of process exit) when a node stops or fails.\n"
                 "Also see the listunspent call\n",
body: while touching this help, can you add the missing full stop between "call" and the newline? e.g. `call.\n`

diff_hunk:
@@ -2047,6 +2047,7 @@ static UniValue lockunspent(const JSONRPCRequest& request)
                 "Temporarily lock (unlock=false) or unlock (unlock=true) specified transaction outputs.\n"
                 "If no transaction outputs are specified when unlocking then all current locked transaction outputs are unlocked.\n"
                 "A locked transaction output will not be chosen by automatic coin selection, when spending bitcoins.\n"
+                "Manually selected coins are automatically unlocked.\n"
body: This is incorrect, or am I missing something? I mean, all spent coins are unlocked right?
mirco-nit if you retouch: empty line seems misplaced

diff_hunk:
@@ -2047,6 +2047,7 @@ static UniValue lockunspent(const JSONRPCRequest& request)
                 "Temporarily lock (unlock=false) or unlock (unlock=true) specified transaction outputs.\n"
                 "If no transaction outputs are specified when unlocking then all current locked transaction outputs are unlocked.\n"
                 "A locked transaction output will not be chosen by automatic coin selection, when spending bitcoins.\n"
+                "Manually selected coins are automatically unlocked.\n"
body: Yes, but that's not the point. Automatically selection avoids locks, manually selection causes an unlock. This remark protects a user who assumes locked coins can't be accidentally spend by manually picking them. (it's like the difference between a Japanese toilet with shoes in front of it indicating it's occupied, and a Dutch toilets that's locked like a vault because people just pull the door open to find out)

diff_hunk:
@@ -2047,6 +2047,7 @@ static UniValue lockunspent(const JSONRPCRequest& request)
                 "Temporarily lock (unlock=false) or unlock (unlock=true) specified transaction outputs.\n"
                 "If no transaction outputs are specified when unlocking then all current locked transaction outputs are unlocked.\n"
                 "A locked transaction output will not be chosen by automatic coin selection, when spending bitcoins.\n"
+                "Manually selected coins are automatically unlocked.\n"
body: I think "Locks on manually selected coins are ignored." would be a more intuitive description of what happens but I understand this to mean the same thing.
